facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1391 of 1967

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1391 of 1967.

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 4 of 1960

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 31, 1963 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 4 of 1960.

facts.text: The appeal is by certificate by the Revenue against the order of the Calcutta High Court

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by certificate by the Revenue is directed against the order made by the High Court of Calcutta in a reference under s. 66(1)

facts.text: The reference to High Court was under section 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 at the instance of the assessee by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal A Bench, Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 to be hereinafter referred to as the Act. At the instance of the assessee, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal A Bench, Calcutta referred

facts.text: Two questions of law were referred to the High Court

anchor.surface_text: to the High Court for its opinion two questions of law viz. Whether the assessment is complete on the date when the income is assessed by the Income-tax Officer or on the date when the tax is computed by him and the challan demanding the tax is issued? Whether on the facts

facts.text: Original assessment of the assessee for assessment year 1944-45 was made sometime before March 13, 1953

anchor.surface_text: The original assessment of the assessee for the assessment year 1944-45 was made sometime before March 13, 1953.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer obtained sanction of the Commissioner of Income-tax and reopened the assessment under s.34(1)(a) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Sub- sequently after obtaining the sanction of the Commissioner of Income-tax, the Income-tax Officer reopened the assessment under s. 34(1)(a) of the Act.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice to the assessee under s.34 read with s.22(2) of the Act on March 13, 1953

anchor.surface_text: On March 13, 1953 he issued a notice to the assessee under s. 34 read with s. 22(2) of the Act.

facts.text: After considering objection of the assessee, Income-tax Officer computed income of assessee under s.34 read with s.23(4) on March 8, 1954 at Rs. 60,000

anchor.surface_text: After considering the objection of the assessee, the Income-tax Officer computed the income of the assessee under s. 34 read with s. 23(4) on March 8, 1954 at Rs. 60,000.

facts.text: Entry made by Income-tax Officer on March 8, 1954 in order sheet reads 'Assessed as per assessment order on a total income of Rs. 60,000 for the assessment year 1944-45 under s. 34/23(4)'

anchor.surface_text: The entry made by the Income-tax Officer on that day in the order sheet reads Assessed as per assessment order on a total income of Rs. 60,000 for the assessment year 1944-45 under s. 34/23(4).

facts.text: On March 8, 1954 the Income-tax Officer did not determine the tax due from the assessee

anchor.surface_text: But on that date the Income-tax Officer did not determine the tax due from the assessee.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer determined the tax due from the assessee and issued notice under s.28(3) in Form 30 on March 31, 1954

anchor.surface_text: It appears that he determined the tax due from the assessee and issued a notice under s. 28(3) in Form 30 only on March 31, 1954.

facts.text: Assessee contended that the assessment is barred under s.34(3)

anchor.surface_text: The assessee contended that the assessment is barred under s. 34(3).

facts.text: Assessee's contention that assessment barred under s.34(3) was rejected by authorities under the Act including appellate tribunal

anchor.surface_text: That contention was rejected by the authorities under the Act including the appellate tribunal

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal made reference to High Court on questions of law

anchor.surface_text: but on a reference made by the tribunal to the High Court,

facts.text: Calcutta High Court accepted assessee's contention following Madras High Court decision in M. P. R. Viswanathan Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income Tax

anchor.surface_text: the High Court following the decision of the Madras High Court in M. P. R. Viswanathan Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras accepted the contention of the assessee

facts.text: Madras High Court in Viswanathan Chettiar's case concluded on September 24, 1953 that word assessment in proviso to s.34(3) means computation of income and determination of tax payable

anchor.surface_text: As long back as September 24, 1953, the High Court of Madras in Viswanathan Chettiars case came to the conclusion that the word assessment in proviso to s. 34(3) means not merely the computation

facts.text: No other High Court has taken a contrary view to Madras High Court decision

anchor.surface_text: No other High Court has taken a contrary view.

facts.text: Revenue acted on the basis of Madras High Court decision for years

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue must have in all these years acted on the basis of that decision of the Madras High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 3 -No order of assessment under section 23 to which clause  c  of sub-section  1  of section 28  1  25, I.T.R. 79. applies or of assessment or reassessment in cases falling within clause  a  of sub-section  1  of this section shall be made after the expiry of 8 years and numberorder of assessment or re-assessment in any other case shall be made after the expiry of 4 years from the end of the year in which the income, profits or claims were first assessable Provided that where a numberice under sub-section  1  has been issued within the time therein limited, the assessment or re-assessment to be made in pursuance of such numberice may be made before the expiry of one year from the date of the service of the numberice even if such period exceeds the period of 8 years or 4 years as the case may be.

anchor.surface_text: 23 1 . If the Income-tax Officer is satisfied without requiring the presence of the assessee or the production by him of any evidence that a return made under section 22 is companyrect and companyplete, he shall assess the total income of the assessee, and shall determine the sum payable by him on the basis of such return. If the Income-tax Officer is number satisfied without requiring the presence of the person who made the return or the production of evidence that return made under section 22 is companyrect and companyplete, he shall serve on such person a numberice requiring him, on a date to be therein specified, either to attend at the Income-tax Officers Office or to produce, or to cause to be there produced, any evidence on which such person may rely in support of the return. On the day specified in the numberice issued under sub-section  2  or as soon afterwards as may be, the Income-tax Officer, after hearing such evidence as such person may produce and such other evidence as the Income- tax Officer may require, on specified points, shall by an order in writing, assess the total income of the assessee, and determine the sum payable by him on the basis of such assessment. If any person falls to make the return required by any numberice given under subsection  2  of section 22 and has number made a return or a revised return under sub-section  3  of the same section or fails to companyply with all the terms of a numberice issued under sub-section  4  of the same section or, having made a return, fails to companyply with all the terms of a, numberice issued under subsection  2  of the section, the Income-tax Officer shall make the assessment to the best of his judgment and determine the sum payable by the assessee on the basis of such assessment.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court followed it as persuasive, no contrary views, acted upon by Revenue

arguments.claim: Words 'assessment' and 'assessee' have different meanings in different provisions depending on context and purpose

anchor.surface_text: It has been stated over and over again by this Court as well as by the Judicial Committee that the words assessment and the assessee are used in different places in the Act with different meaning. Therefore in finding out the true meaning of those words in any provision, we have to see to the context in which the word is used and the purpose intended to be achieved.

arguments.claim: In s.23, 'assess' refers to computation of income, not determination of tax liability

anchor.surface_text: It is true that sub-ss. 1, 3 and 4 of s. 23 require the Income-tax Officer to assess the total income of the assessee and determine the sum payable by him. In other words in those provisions the word assess has been used with reference to computation of the income of the assessee and not the determination of his tax liability.

arguments.claim: No other High Court has taken a contrary view to Madras High Court

anchor.surface_text: No other High Court has taken a contrary view.

arguments.claim: Long-standing interpretation in taxing statute accepted and acted upon by Revenue should not be departed from to avoid unsettling settled law

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue must have in all these years acted on the basis of that decision of the Madras High Court. Interpretation of a provision in a taxing statute rendered years back and accepted and acted upon by the department should not be easily departed from. It may be that another view of the law is possible but law is not a mere mental exercise. The courts while reconsidering the decisions rendered long time back particularly under taxing statutes cannot ignore the harm that is likely to happen by unsettling law that had been once settled.

arguments.qualifiers: It may be that another view of the law is possible

arguments.claim: Not justified in departing from Madras High Court interpretation though different view possible

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances we do not think that we would be justified in departing from the interpretation placed by the Madras High Court in Viswanathan Chettiars case though a different view of the law may be reasonably possible.

arguments.qualifiers: though a different view of the law may be reasonably possible

holdings.text: the word assessment in proviso to s. 34(3) means not merely the computation of the income of the assessee but also the determination of the tax payable by him

anchor.surface_text: As long back as September 24, 1953, the High Court of Madras in Viswanathan Chettiars case came to the conclusion that the word assessment in proviso to s. 34(3) means not merely the computation of the income of the assessee but also the determination of the tax payable by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorsed Madras High Court interpretation from 1953 with no contrary High Court views, Revenue reliance over years, and policy against unsettling settled tax law

holdings.text: this appeal fails and the same is dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal fails and the same is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax determination on March 31, 1954 exceeded one-year period from notice of March 13, 1953 under proviso to s.34(3) after applying interpretation of 'assessment'

holdings.text: the words assessment and the assessee are used in different places in the Act with different meaning. Therefore in finding out the true meaning of those words in any provision, we have to see to the context in which the word is used and the purpose intended to be achieved

anchor.surface_text: It has been stated over and over again by this Court as well as by the Judicial Committee that the words assessment and the assessee are used in different places in the Act with different meaning. Therefore in finding out the true meaning of those words in any provision, we have to see to the context in which the word is used and the purpose intended to be achieved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restated from prior decisions of this Court and Judicial Committee

holdings.text: in those provisions the word assess has been used with reference to computation of the income of the assessee and not the determination of his tax liability

anchor.surface_text: It is true that sub-ss. 1, 3 and 4 of s. 23 require the Income-tax Officer to assess the total income of the assessee and determine the sum payable by him. In other words in those provisions the word assess has been used with reference to computation of the income of the assessee and not the determination of his tax liability.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of ss.1,3,4 of s.23 distinguishes from usage in s.34(3)

holdings.text: Interpretation of a provision in a taxing statute rendered years back and accepted and acted upon by the department should not be easily departed from

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue must have in all these years acted on the basis of that decision of the Madras High Court. Interpretation of a provision in a taxing statute rendered years back and accepted and acted upon by the department should not be easily departed from. It may be that another view of the law is possible but law is not a mere mental exercise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prevents harm from unsettling law relied upon by Revenue even if alternative view possible

holdings.text: The corresponding provisions of the 1961 Act are materially different from the provisions referred to earlier

anchor.surface_text: We may also note that the Act has been repealed by the Income-tax Act, 1961. The corresponding provisions of the1961 Act are materially different from the provisions referred to earlier.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observes legislative change post-1922 Act for contextual note
